awd_titl_txt: CAREER: How Power Corrupts: Power Offers Immunity to the Emotional, Cognitive, and Physiological Stress of Corrupt Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
There is no shortage of examples of the link between power and corruption, but how does power corrupt? Ironically, existing research has demonstrated many of the benefits of power: power enhances cognitive function, facilitates an adaptive approach motivation, and the powerful enjoy disease resistance. How then can power lead to corruption and such incredibly adaptive outcomes?  This CAREER research project examines the link between power and corruption by systematically testing the extent to which power provides a physiological immunity to stressors. According to this perspective, the basic physiological architecture of human beings actually facilitates corruption unless individuals are aware and motivated to circumvent it. The current proposal outlines a research program in the neuroscience of how power corrupts. The proposed research focuses on the "power-as-immunity" theory which explains how power -through a stress buffering mechanism- lowers the emotional, cognitive, and physiological costs of all kinds of stressful things, good and corrupt.  The theory transforms and extends current theories about power by describing the basic mechanisms through which power shapes emotion, cognition, and behavior. The 12 proposed experiments will help science to further understand the basic effect of power on stress as well as when the stress-buffering mechanism leads to corruption and the exact mechanisms which underlie the stress-buffering effect of power.

The researcher will partner with a leadership and ethics center at HAAS Business School to develop new ethics curricula to be immediately integrated into the core MBA curriculum. The aim is to develop an entire ethics module for undergraduate and graduate level business students using interactive, role-play based business cases which will be widely available to anyone at any school interested in enhancing ethics training. The project also involves rigorous training of undergraduate and graduate students who will gain expertise in social neuroscience methods.  Ultimately, this work which is focused on power's effect on corruption will offer practical insight and training for tomorrow's business leaders.

por.por_cntn:
The Five-year support for the project entitled “How Power Corrupts: Power Offers Immunity to the Emotional, Cognitive, and Physiological Stress of Corrupt Behavior” allowed for the production of 5 published reports in top journals, and additional 15 experiments that are still in the process of being published as 6 different papers, the direct training of at least 15 undergraduates 7 of who were shepherded into PhD programs and 2 of who were from underrepresented social groups in psychology. 3 graduate students were successfully trained under this grant and 4 post-doctoral fellows (supported by other grants) participated in the research (3 have faculty jobs and one is a senior researcher at Google).

The overall findings supported the basic hypothesis outlined in the title which is that power leads to all kinds of action regardless of whether that action is beneficial or costly to the self or to others. In other words, sometimes the power-to-action is a good thing and other times it can be corrupt (lying, cheating, stealing, etc). And the physiological evidence we found suggested that power leads to this action through the stressors seeming not to be so stressful—as if power is *buffering* people from stress. In these experiments, power was leading to some kind of cognitive or physiological change that leads to a reduction in stress reactivity to stressors. Stress reactivity in these experiments was measured by examining self-reported experiences, coding facial expressions associated with fear and stress, by examining threat reactions indexed by a physiological tool called pulse plethysmography and by examining a hormone that is often secreted when a person feels stress- cortisol. In addition to providing a number of presentations and publications for me and my students, and for providing an incredibly rich training environment for so many students and post docs, the main findings—that power buffers us from stressors and that can lead to corruption is something that has been taught to thousands of undergraduate business students, hundreds of MBA students, and hundreds of business executives from the Los Alamos National Labs to CEOs of major tech and semiconductor companies in Silicon Valley and to Wall Street executives in New York City.

The direct findings also led to two new discoveries that opened up two new, related, research paths: (1) we discovered that power and deception were linked in a number of ways. Possessing power allowed people to lie more effectively and lacking power made people very easy to “catch” when telling a lie. We also found that powerlessness led people to become better lie-detectors. Putting all of these findings together than came from the NSF CAREER grant set us on a new, independent path where we began to test and theorize about conditions under which ordinary people could detect deception. This has led to a number of spinoff empirical papers and a theoretical paper published in the highly cited journal Trends in Cognitive Sciences. Another path that the NSF grant opened came from the repeatedly emerging finding that (2) people high on power were not less inhibited—in fact they seemed to lack more control – for example they were able to lie more effectively, keep their arms in a bucket of cold ice water longer and other forms of physical or cognitive restraint. And so a second spinoff set of projects was born directly from the findings in the NSF grant on the link between higher vertical position (e.g., higher power, status, SES) and increases in physical, emotional and cognitive restraints. We now have 2 large field studies and 5 experiments in this new line of work—all of which came directly from our initial theorizing about the NSF CAREER project -- how power offers immunity to the emotional, cognitive, and physiological stress of corrupt behavior.
